title: Grade 12 - Human Development throughout the Lifespan HHG4M (2013)
subject: Social Science and Humanities

document.title: Grade 12 - Human Development throughout the Lifespan HHG4M (2013)

7305683EA0074832A2FAB3B7FBA937F6.description: assess the impact of marginalization (e.g., marginalization related to factors such as age, poverty, disability, gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity, religion, low literacy levels) on socialemotional development

8AD8EF4039664AEE9127A5A5A0175925.description: analyse the effects of socialization on the social-emotional functioning of individuals throughout the lifespan (e.g., with respect to individuals' values, behaviour, and sense of social responsibility; their ability to adjust to change, balance work and leisure, engage and communicate with other people and maintain relationships; their response to peer pressure, discrimination; the relationship between poor socialization and defiance, delinquency, and disengagement)

595C52A2F4A94461B9EBF0D7FA507874.description: analyse the role that family plays in socializing its members (e.g., with reference to the development of language, communication skills, confidence, competence, and self-esteem, and to the transmission of gender roles, culture, religion, and values such as respect for elders and for the environment)

692A686D286A4978BE4520F88B08ABFA.description: Factors Affecting Social-Emotional Development: demonstrate an understanding of how factors affect social-emotional development, with an emphasis on the process of socialization.

9FE74AE921BE457BB2B0DDC263C798E9.description: analyse the relationship between personality and social interactions (e.g., the differences that introverted and extraverted people might experience in their social interactions; the impact on one's personality of nurturing, supportive, empathetic interactions and critical, controlling ones)

3A40A11237154191BD349FE48EDF8FEE.description: explain how birth order and temperament can affect the development of an individual's personality

96E9C790EA8541E9BA21D1D0FF648130.description: explain the process of identity formation throughout the lifespan (e.g., with reference to gender identity, ethnic identity, identity statuses)

8E362272F345461C9F095EBA9AEC027D.description: explain the effects that secure and insecure attachment in the early years can have on social-emotional development in adolescence and adulthood

F851D22CC0644A2FBA2E34A34121C634.description: describe ways in which parents and caregivers can promote secure attachment in infants and children (e.g., nurturing, responsive care, breastfeeding)

702D7B4EC975412295BC14ACAFE56B39.description: describe the development of emotion throughout the lifespan (e.g., early emotions, stranger anxiety, emotional fluctuations, socioemotional selectivity)

6B7DC50B940A4D6AAFE7510D529611AD.description: explain attachment theory as it relates to human development (e.g., with reference to the theories of John Bowlby, Mary Ainsworth, Kim Batholomew)

0BAF4D93360A490083A00693D48CAE39.description: Social-Emotional Development: demonstrate an understanding of social-emotional development throughout the lifespan and of ways of influencing such development;

377D8346BE824AB7B1CF2E642608F810.description: evaluate the effects of rapidly changing technology on cognitive development and language use throughout the lifespan (e.g., the effects of increased use of texting language, the effects on cognitive processing speed)

AEBC0312DDA64BDB90D768C9DA16878C.description: explain the effects of individual differences (e.g., differences related to giftedness, developmental delays, attention deficit disorder, autism, school anxiety, aphasia, depression, schizophrenia, dementia, Alzheimer's, birth order, gender) on cognitive development throughout the lifespan

8E30E809FC90493C85F0B291E99F89C5.description: Factors Affecting Cognitive Development and Language Use: analyse the effects of contextual factors on cognitive development and language use throughout the lifespan.

7103ECC3A76E4B5A908AA1EAA12BF3DC.description: analyse current research on the impact of environment on intelligence (e.g., the Fraser Mustard report, the Charles Pascal report)

9EB2B14C25B54367BCFD7DEE5DD07E74.description: explain the limitations of standardized tests of intelligence (e.g., lack of "culture-fair" tests; reliance on language as the basis for testing; stereotype threat)

7D576F9E9A5F4703AE590F8B52022607.description: analyse various aspects of intelligence (e.g., infant intelligence, multiple intelligences, social intelligence, emotional intelligence, fluid and crystallized intelligence)

4AA65ADFF9F949DEA890C8D56C3CF035.description: Intelligence: demonstrate an understanding of issues related to defining, measuring, and developing intelligence;

3D4B098E77314B6C912141ACF70F1F01.description: explain the processes of language acquisition and development throughout the lifespan

C68561123A594B7FAB14EF97A3B138D7.description: explain the physiological foundations of language development (e.g., the areas of the brain related to language processing)

CA18800E065A4D0EB06D93FC740CBE8D.description: Language Acquisition and Development: explain the processes and physiological foundations of language acquisition and development throughout the lifespan;

B72C15DB887D4126B1C18D185E020AD7.description: explain how information processing changes throughout the lifespan (e.g., with reference to short- and long-term memory, critical thinking, problem solving, decision making), with emphasis on changes in attention, memory, thinking, and metacognition

7AAE8F5586774220B96F1B33AC821B26.description: describe cognitive development throughout the lifespan (e.g., the development of theory of mind in preschoolers, dualistic thinking of adolescents, reflective thinking of adults, wisdom in later adulthood)

60B973FEA5C948349E77E6D2C9FE419F.description: explain theories of moral development (e.g., the theories of Lawrence Kohlberg, Carol Gilligan, Moshe Blatt, James Rest)

B4279434BF7F4D0AB3BBBD4304999925.description: explain theories of human cognitive development (e.g., the theories of Jean Piaget, Lev Vygotsky, Noam Chomsky, Maria Montessori, Robert J. Sternberg)

EBB973B876B44F1D816AF0954AEA3E38.description: Cognitive Development: demonstrate an understanding of theories of cognitive development and of changes in aspects of cognitive development throughout the lifespan;

6A269D8835634397BBC34CD8ED7519F5.description: Cognitive Development, Language Development, and Intelligence

21F3FDA65FD04D4B92A0901376C05F9B.description: describe brain plasticity with reference to the brain's response to injury, illness, and environmental factors (e.g., physical injuries, strokes, aphasia, stress, substance abuse, infectious diseases, environmental toxins, nutritional deficiencies)

C2D416F8B9BC4DE183839E355D6B6503.description: identify factors that can affect brain development during the prenatal period (e.g., maternal and paternal illness; maternal stress, substance abuse, or nutritional deficiencies; advanced maternal or paternal age; teratogens; some prescription drugs; environmental pollutants; infectious diseases), and analyse their impact

0D5C80E847F3498887600A5F90581206.description: analyse the long-term effects of early environmental stimulation and deprivation on brain development (e.g., stimulation produces a heavier brain with thicker layers, more neural connections, and greater neurochemical activity; deprivation hinders brain activity)

539A4AD1F9854A17BA534A0FB7D88F64.description: explain how various factors affect physical development throughout the lifespan (e.g., illness, injury, genetic factors, nutrition, exercise)

E83369AF0C50406EB309A5F76105DD2B.description: Factors Affecting Physical Development: demonstrate an understanding of contextual factors that can affect physical development, particularly brain development, throughout the lifespan and of the effects of these factors.

8CE73FE772D54E6AAE96DB073E20B62D.description: describe changes to sensory faculties and motor skills in later life (e.g., presbyopia, presbycusis, decline in taste buds, reduced muscle strength and bone density, slower reflexes), and explain strategies that can be used to slow, prevent, or otherwise address their decline (e.g., doing regular cardiovascular and weightbearing exercise, practising good nutrition, wearing ear protection when working around loud noises, having cataract surgery, wearing a hearing aid)

2D7C90F6295B4D71B28CD97CF62CDA95.description: analyse the major milestones in motor skills development in the early years of life (e.g., milestones related to reflexes, gross motor skills, fine motor skills)

4B79BF56D68C46BA82D9AB8A66FADF39.description: Sensory and Motor Development: demonstrate an understanding of sensory and motor development at different stages of the lifespan;

30569096D2784CAC8F07C79CD711136B.description:
describe the development of the brain from
the prenatal period through the elder years, with
particular emphasis on significant changes that
occur throughout the lifespan (e.g., neuron formation, neural tube development, neurogenesis,
neuronal migration, myelination, synaptogenesis,Â development of the prefrontal cortex, peak periods of
growth for each brain lobe, synaptic pruning, brain
shrinkage, slowing of brain function)

EC9FB07355F54E9BA7C54131A8A2F220.description: describe human brain physiology, including key structures and their functions (e.g., the brainstem is responsible for basic vital life functions such as breathing; the cerebellum is responsible for movement, posture, and balance)

6AA8FC6FBCD54D2DB0FBC33F97A62E8C.description: describe the major changes in the body throughout the lifespan (e.g., cephalocaudal and proximodistal patterns of growth in infancy and childhood; changes associated with puberty; changes related to sex drive, sexual attraction, and reproduction; changes associated with menopause; physical changes in elderly people)

FA9D615DFFBA4EAC85682C13D51C1A56.description: explain theories of human physical development (e.g., the theories of Arnold Gesell, Esther Thelen)

907C657ED6B24D3EB4519BA0DD91D7A4.description: Physical Development and Brain Physiology: demonstrate an understanding of physical development, including brain physiology and development, throughout the lifespan;

BB5DA8D02A1042FCAF4AA3D436666CAC.description: describe opportunities for involvement in local community initiatives that address challenges to human development (e.g., school-wide fundraising for organizations providing support to children and families; food drives; volunteer opportunities with literacy initiatives, in Big Brothers/Big Sisters, at retirement homes)

DB8081CAB43B46279139073A7ED1607B.description: describe ways in which government policies and initiatives by non-governmental organizations (NGOs) at the local and global levels can function as protective factors that reduce the impact of threats to human development at different stages of the lifespan (e.g., government policies supporting full-day Kindergarten, parental leave, and preventive health care; establishing green space; combating global climate change; NGO initiatives such as the Stephen Lewis Foundation's support for grandmothers raising grandchildren orphaned by AIDS or Planned Parenthood's maternal health programs)

464105E02E3B49F4AC01E85F38AA4F76.description: explain how protective factors at the individual, familial, and community levels (e.g., intelligence; strong relationships with one or more adults; exposure to enriched learning environments; community supports such as Meals on Wheels, senior centres, literacy centres) can promote resilience in individuals

C0FE8ADA7CE644BDBEE79182FDEF0E6D.description: describe threats to healthy development and their impact at various stages of life (e.g., poverty, discrimination, political unrest, environmental degradation, physical and mental illness, substance abuse, physical/sexual abuse)

0FF128B35A40449EA27B8B7BB515AE01.description: Risk and Resilience: demonstrate an understanding of threats to healthy development throughout the lifespan and of a variety of protective factors that can increase an individual's resilience and reduce the impact of these threats.

E9D2DAC98BF2414E9E0278EDF98CB4B5.description: explain human development throughout the lifespan according to systemic and humanistic theoretical perspectives (e.g., the theories of Urie Bronfenbrenner, Abraham Maslow, Carl Rogers, Bonnie Burstow, Barbara Rogoff)

9FDD145B453243F89D6C76FED3B11427.description: explain human development throughout the lifespan according to information-processing and learning theoretical perspectives (e.g., the theories of Ivan Pavlov, B. F. Skinner, John B. Watson, Albert Bandura)

B2FD05CCE98A42768ABC899864EE6B1A.description: explain human development throughout the lifespan according to structuralist theoretical perspectives (e.g., the stage theories of Sigmund Freud, Erik Erikson, Jean Piaget)

80C516B868D74C8DAAB1A54C43B8FEB1.description: Theoretical Perspectives: demonstrate an understanding of a variety of theoretical perspectives on human development;

33E6F05C2AF3465D8026F4769A4ED4BA.description: Developmental Theories, and Risk and Resilience

6DEFFBBB5B724E7FA9C86C1FC68BEABB.description: demonstrate an understanding of the general research process by reflecting on and evaluating their own research, inquiry, and communication skills

2EB7095510BB4F68A6524674D55D0D27.description: clearly communicate the results of their inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly), and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources (e.g., generate a reference list in APA style, use in-text author-date citations)

E9FFC6EE683C49BD904ED5048B9F1315.description: use terms relating to human development correctly (e.g., risk, resilience, protective factor, attachment, plasticity, identity, temperament)

3C8CA14B4451437B92852F201BD1C904.description: use an appropriate format (e.g., oral presentation, written research report, poster, multimedia presentation, web page) to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience

5A47CDB326FD4E3B953168D4661429B1.description: Communicating and Reflecting: communicate the results of their research and inquiry clearly and effectively, and reflect on and evaluate their research, inquiry, and communication skills

70A64DCCB7A84359B9568A2B00500159.description: synthesize findings and formulate conclusions (e.g., determine whether their results support or contradict their hypothesis; weigh and connect information to determine the answer to their research questions; assess the extent to which their results may be affected by "confounding variables" - i.e., variables not controlled for in their research design)

E840F218357C4941B3DF453319A087AC.description: demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research

5BCC0549CF1F464AB03D0FE1C41A50A9.description: analyse and interpret research information (e.g., compare information gathered from primary and secondary sources; determine whether similar information is found in different sources)

A6D378B8C4BC4AD09C5240E7C549C4E8.description: record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats (e.g., notes, graphic organizers, summaries, audio/digital records)

45FBCFE800F440EFB591646885C3350A.description: assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice)

2F9E5E09D8EF4732B92AA0E0A89ADA44.description: Processing Information: assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry;

2A70A5CD40C14904BDFA0A5D03CEA74B.description: based on preliminary research, for each investigation formulate a hypothesis, thesis statement, or research question, and use it to focus their research

240F8C0162CD425F87BFA9E1F36F632E.description: locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources (e.g., interviews; observations; surveys and questionnaires; journal articles reporting on original research; original documents in print or other media such as film, photographs) and secondary sources (e.g., textbooks, literature reviews, bibliographies, encyclopedias)

4D96F53B568D4E16A4F218587E3E6D28.description: create appropriate research plans to investigate their selected topics (e.g., outline purpose and method; identify sources of information; develop HIF10/20 Human Development throughout the Lifespan HHG4M research tools such as surveys or questionnaires), ensuring that their plans follow guidelines for ethical research

E65F94CCA64E440F9BE17809998136F7.description: Investigating: create research plans, and locate and select information relevant to their chosen topics, using appropriate social science research and inquiry methods;

2062D3609AD44652A399583F241DF01D.description: formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry

3E8F5FA5AAE1407BB85D08D59FEADFBF.description: identify key concepts (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers) related to their selected topics

D3E9A172AC394423816B73DD07174D02.description: explore a variety of topics related to human development (e.g., brain development, effects of play on development, language development) to identify topics for research and inquiry

282CE031BFB84E359A6FEFC2E0D65C3C.description: Exploring: explore topics related to human development, and formulate questions to guide their research;
